In an address delivered March
23 at the Founder's Day
exercises of The College of
Charleston (SC), President Muller
recently addressed the topic of
higher education as it exists
today and forecasted its future
direction.
Drawing a direct comparison
between the developing society
and the nature of undergraduate

Muller criticized these institutes
of higher learning as factories of

playgrounds for advanced
thinkers.
"America has become used to
looking to higher education for
advanced skills. Universities have
also been asked increasingly to
solve some of the problems of

sensationalized, distrustful
people that looks to the

university mirrors the image of

integrating focus."

priority of humanistic studies far
below that of advanced skilling,
were inadequage.

cure," Muller stated.

Track team off to running start
By JOHN TETZLAFF
The 1974 Hopkins track team
is off to a fast start, compiling a
4-1 record after its first three
outings. A sport which
unfortunately receives little fan
support, the Homewood
cindermen hope to change that as
the outlook for this season is a
bright one.
The cindermen easily defeated
Franklin and Marshall and
Swarthmore by the score
81-60-39 on a cold rainy day at
F&M on March 31. The team was
led by triple wins from
co-captain Gerry Greenfield (high
hurdles, intermediate hurdles.
high jump) and Oscar Schreiber
(long and triple jumps, 440 yd.
dash).
Last Wednesday, the team
travelled to Gettysburg, splitting
the tri-meet with Gettysburg and

Albright by the score of
98-68-15. In the match with
powerful‘Z.;ettysburg the Blue Jays
needed its nest effort in all areas,
and it just wasn't there.
Team leader was again Gerry
Greenfield, winning both hurdles
races to go with seconds in the
high jump and 160 yd. dash.
Junior John Viel had a personal
best in winning the javelin at 181
feet, 5 inches.
Hylind Streaks, Hurdles
Jim Kennedy had the strongest
distance double in recent
memory, with seconds in the
midle, and two mile at 4:32 and
9:36. Both times were personal
highs. Also encouraging were the
pair of third places from Mark
Hylind in the hurdle , as well as
the second consecutive scoring
effort from freshman Brett Miles

in the long jump.
On Saturday the thinclads
easily defeated UMBC 85-51 on
Homewood Field. The power of
the field team showed itself
clearly with wins fro co-capain
Al Shiff in the shot-put and
seconds in both the shot and the
discus from freshman George
Skegas. Oscar Schreiber was a
double winner in the triple and
long jumps with Earl Dryer
adding second and third
respectively. Stu Dickinson
added further strength in the
field events with a victory in the
pole vault.
On the track. Gerry Greenfield
was a triple winner again taking
both sprints, as well as the
intermediate hurdles. Junior John
Higdon won his second mile of
the season in 4:36 and Dryer
took third in the 440.
